{{For|the 2015 Australian TV mini-series|The Principal (TV series)}} {{other uses|Principal (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox film | name = The Principal | image = Principalposter1987.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Christopher Cain]] | producer = [[Thomas H. Brodek]] | writer = [[Frank Deese]] | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[James Belushi]] * [[Louis Gossett, Jr.]] * [[Rae Dawn Chong]] * [[Kelly Jo Minter|Kelly Minter]] }} | music = [[Jay Gruska]] | cinematography = [[Arthur Albert]] | editing = [[Jack Hofstra]] | studio = [[Dorica Film]]
[[ML Delphi Premier Productions]] | distributor = [[TriStar Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1987|9|15}} | runtime = 109 minutes | country = United States | language = English | gross = $19,734,940 (USA) }} '''''The Principal''''' is a 1987 [[crime-thriller|crime thriller]] [[action film]] starring [[Jim Belushi]] and [[Louis Gossett, Jr.]] It was written by Frank Deese and directed by [[Christopher Cain]]. It was filmed in [[Oakland, California]] and distributed by [[TriStar Pictures]] on [[Panavision]]. Belushi reprised his role as Rick Latimer in the 1990 film ''[[Abraxas, Guardian of the Universe]]''. ==Plot== Rick Latimer ([[Jim Belushi]]) is a high-school teacher with a drinking problem. Spotting his ex-wife Kimberly ([[Sharon Thomas|Sharon Thomas Cain]]) in a bar one night, Rick gets into a fight with the man she is with, culminating in his beating the hapless man's car with a baseball bat. The board of education finds that Rick's behavior is reflecting poorly on the school district's image. They unanimously decide to transfer him to another school, in another district: Brandel High, a crime-ridden and gang-dominated institution, where he is made the new principal. Believing he can repair his image by cleaning up the school, Rick attempts to have an assembly to declare his intentions: "No more." No more drugs, running in the hallways or being late to class. While he's giving his speech, Victor Duncan ([[Michael Wright (actor)|Michael Wright]]), the leader of the main gang in the school, walks in, derides Rick in front of everyone, then walks out, which eventually results in a small riot, which earns Rick the enmity of not only the teachers but also school head of security Jake ([[Lou Gossett Jr.]]). Eventually, Rick manages to enforce his policy of getting rid of the drugs being dealt in the bathrooms and clearing out the hallways — but not always with success. Because the students are now forced to go to class, some of the more unruly students become increasingly disruptive, including White Zac ([[J.J. Cohen]]), who eventually attempts to [[rape]] one of the teachers, Ms. Orozco ([[Rae Dawn Chong]]), with whom Rick is beginning to form a close friendship. Victor, meanwhile, continues to assert his influence on the school, going so far as to brutally beat a former member of his gang and hang him by his ankles when the member warms to Rick and actually starts learning. The clash between Rick and Victor eventually leads to a showdown in the school halls, where Jake is temporarily locked inside a supply closet while Victor and his gang hunt Rick down. In the end, Victor and Rick fight each other with their fists, with Victor seemingly having the upper hand until Rick overpowers him. Rick beats Victor, much to the shock of the rest of the school who witness the beating. Several students cheer Rick on, much to the chagrin of Victor's gang members. After a small fight breaks out Rick again declares, "No more!" Victor is taken away in a police car, and as a student derisively asks, "Hey man, who the hell do you think you are?", Rick responds "I'm the principal, man!" and rides away on his motorcycle. ==Cast== * [[Jim Belushi]] as Principal Rick Latimer * [[Louis Gossett, Jr.]] as head guard Jake Phillips * [[Rae Dawn Chong]] as teacher Hilary Orozco * [[Michael Wright (actor)|Michael Wright]] as gang leader Victor Duncan * [[J.J. Cohen|Jeffrey Jay Cohen]] as White Zac * [[Kelly Jo Minter|Kelly Minter]] as Treena Lester * [[Esai Morales]] as Raymi Rojas * [[Troy Winbush]] as Baby Emile * [[Jacob Vargas]] as Arturo Diego ==Box office== ''The Principal'' had moderate success at the box office.{{cite news|title= Weekend Box Office|publisher= [[Los Angeles Times]]|date=|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1987-09-29/entertainment/ca-10882_1_weekend-box-office|accessdate=2012-06-03}} The domestic total gross for the film was $19,734,940.{{cite web| url= http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=main&id=principal.htm|title= The Principal |publisher= IMDB.com |accessdate=August 13, 2012}} ==Reception== In 2014, the movie was one of several discussed by [[Keli Goff]] in ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' in an article concerning [[White savior narrative in film|white savior narratives in film]].{{cite news | last=Goff | first=Keli | url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/05/04/can-belle-end-hollywood-s-obsession-with-the-white-savior.html | title=Can 'Belle' End Hollywood's Obsession with the White Savior? | work=[[The Daily Beast]] | date=May 4, 2014 | accessdate=May 14, 2014 }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0093780|The Principal}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes|principal}} * {{Amg movie|39226|The Principal}} * {{tcmdb title|id=39226}} * {{AFI film|id=57789|title=The Principal}} {{Christopher Cain}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Principal, The}} [[Category:1987 films]] [[Category:American comedy-drama films]] [[Category:American action films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:1980s action films]] [[Category:American action thriller films]] [[Category:1980s action thriller films]] [[Category:American thriller films]] [[Category:1980s thriller films]] [[Category:Films about drugs]] [[Category:Films about educators]] [[Category:Films about rape]] [[Category:Films about school violence]] [[Category:Films set in San Francisco]] [[Category:Films set in the San Francisco Bay Area]] [[Category:Films shot in California]] [[Category:American gang films]] [[Category:1980s high school films]] [[Category:Vigilante films]] [[Category:TriStar Pictures films]] [[Category:Hood films]] [[Category:Films directed by Christopher Cain]]

{{See also|Women's education in the United States}} {{lead too short|date=May 2018}} {{more citations needed|date=May 2018}} [[File:Anandibai Joshee, Kei Okami, and Tabat M. Islambooly.jpg|thumb|[[Woman's Medical College of Pennsylvania]] in 1886: [[Anandibai Joshee]] from India (left) with [[Kei Okami]] from Japan (center) and [[Sabat Islambouli|Sabat Islambooly]] from Syria (right). All three completed their medical studies and each of them was the first woman from their respective countries to obtain a degree in Western medicine.]] This is a '''timeline of women's education'''.
== 11th century ==
* Italy: allegedly the University of Bologna, the first university in the Western world, allows women to study, earn degrees and teach since its foundation in 1088.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unibo.it/en/university/who-we-are/our-history/famous-people-guests-illustrious-students|title=Famous people, guests and illustrious students - University of Bologna|website=www.unibo.it|language=en|access-date=2018-05-17|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171205145127/http://www.unibo.it/en/university/who-we-are/our-history/famous-people-guests-illustrious-students|archivedate=2017-12-05|df=}}</ref>
== 13th century == '''1237'''
* Italy: Bettisia [[Bettisia Gozzadini|Gozzadini]] earns a law degree at the University of Bologna.
'''1239'''
* Italy: Bettisia [[Bettisia Gozzadini|Gozzadini]] teaches Law at the University of Bologna. First woman believed to teach at a university (first university established in 1088).
== 14th century ==
* Italy: Dorotea [[Dorotea Bucca|Bucca]] holds a chair of medicine and philosophy in the university of Bologna for 40 years from 1390.
* Italy: Novella [[Novella d'Andrea|d'Andrea]] teaches Law at the University of Bologna.
== 15th century ==
* Poland: queen Sophie establishes first school for girls in Cracow.
== 16th century ==
* Spain: Luisa de [[Luisa de Medrano|Medrano]] teaches at the University of Salamanca and writes works of philosophy, now lost.
* Spain: Isabella [[Isabella Losa|Losa]] gets a D.D. (Doctor of Divinity) theology degree.
* Spain: Francisca de [[Francisca de Lebrija|Lebrija]] teaches rhetorics at a University of Alcala.
* Spain: Beatriz [[Beatriz Galindo|Galindo]] excels in Latin, studies at one of the institutions dependent on the University of Salamanca, writes commentary on Aristotle and becomes a teacher of the queen. Married, has five children.
==17th century== '''1608''' * Spain: [[Juliana Morell]], a Spanish woman, earns a Law doctorate degree.<ref>[[s:Catholic Encyclopedia (1913)/Juliana Morell|Herbermann, Charles, ed. (1913). "Juliana Morell". Catholic Encyclopedia. Robert Appleton Company.]]</ref><ref name="Paul F. Grendler 1988 328">{{cite book|author=Paul F. Grendler|title=Schools, Seminaries, and Catechetical Instruction, in Catholicism in Early Modern History 1500-1700: A Guide to Research|editor=John W. O'Malley|publisher=Center for Information Research|year=1988|page=328}}</ref> According to Lope de Vega, she taught "all the sciences from professorial chairs".
'''1636''' * Netherlands: German-born Dutch [[Anna Maria van Schurman]], proficient in 14 languages, studied as the first female student at the university of Utrecht, Netherlands, but without obtaining a degree.
'''1639''' * Acadia: The French colony of [[Acadia]], which at the time included part of Maine, had an Ursuline boarding school by 1639 that was geared toward the education of young girls. The school was founded in Quebec City and is still in operation today, though this part of Canada no longer includes the part of Maine that it once did.
'''1644''' * Sweden: first female college students, Ursula Agricola and [[Maria Jonae Palmgren]].
'''1674''' * New Spain: In this year Bishop Calderon of Santiago wrote to Queen Mother Marie Anne of Spain concerning the Spanish efforts at colonizing Florida. In his letter he included some comments about the state of education and stated, "The children, both male and female, go to church on work days, to a religious school where they are taught by a teacher whom they call ''Athequi'' of the church; [a person] whom the priests have for this service."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/documentsofameri00elli#page/22/mode/2up|title=Ellis, John Tracy. Documents of American Catholic History. 1962. Milwaukee, WI: Bruce Publishing Company. p. 22-23.|publisher=|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref> This description indicates that the colonies of New Spain had facilities for female education at least by the 1600s. It is not clear how far back this goes; the 1512 laws of Burgos, from over a hundred years earlier, did not specify whether instruction should be for males only: it uses the word ''hijos'', which means sons, but can include daughters if they are mixed in with the boys.
'''1678''' * Italy: [[Elena Cornaro Piscopia]], an Italian woman, earns a Ph.D. - [[Philosophy doctorate]] degree from the University of Padua in Italy<ref name="Paul F. Grendler 1988 328"/><ref name="agnesscott">{{cite web|url=http://www.agnesscott.edu/lriddle/women/piscopia.htm|title=Elena Lucrezia Cornaro Piscopia|publisher=agnesscott.edu|accessdate=12 January 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219013424/http://www.agnesscott.edu/lriddle/women/piscopia.htm|archivedate=19 December 2013|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.agnesscott.edu/lriddle/women/piscopia.htm |title=Elena Lucrezia Cornaro Piscopia |publisher=Agnesscott.edu |date= |accessdate=2013-09-05 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130904120855/http://www.agnesscott.edu/Lriddle/women/piscopia.htm |archivedate=2013-09-04 |df= }}</ref> and is said to have taught mathematics at the University of Padua. '''1685''' * Italy: Saint Rosa Venerini opens the first gratuitous school for girls in Italy, in the town of Viterbe.
==18th century== '''1727''' * United States: Founded in 1727 by [[Ursulines|the Sisters of the Order of Saint Ursula]], [[Ursuline Academy (New Orleans)|Ursuline Academy, New Orleans]], is both the oldest continuously operating school for girls and the oldest Catholic school in the United States. The Ursuline Sisters founded this school out of the conviction that the education of women was essential to the development of a civilized, spiritual and just society, and has influenced culture and learning in New Orleans by providing an exceptional education for its women.
'''1732''' * Italy: [[Laura Bassi]], an Italian woman, earned a Ph.D. degree at the [[University of Bologna]] in Italy,<ref name="sciencemuseum">{{cite web|url=http://www.sciencemuseum.org.uk/broughttolife/people/laurabassi.aspx|title=Laura Bassi (1711-78)|publisher=sciencemuseum.org.uk|accessdate=12 January 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140103194009/http://www.sciencemuseum.org.uk/broughttolife/people/laurabassi.aspx|archivedate=3 January 2014|df=}}</ref><ref name="Findlen, Paula">Findlen, Paula. Science As A Career In Enlightenment Italy : The Strategies Of Laura Bassi. ''Isis'' 84 (1993): 440-469. History of Science, Technology & Medicine. Web. 3 June 2013."</ref><ref name=Encyclopedia.com>{{cite web| title = Laura Bassi| work = Encyclopedia of World Biography| publisher = Encyclopedia.com| url = http://www.encyclopedia.com/topic/Laura_Bassi.aspx| accessdate = 30 October 2012| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130927062711/http://www.encyclopedia.com/topic/Laura_Bassi.aspx| archivedate = 27 September 2013| df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.epigenesys.eu/index.php/en/science-and-you/women-in-science/663-laura-maria-caterina-bassi |title=Laura Maria Caterina Bassi | Women in science |publisher=Epigenesys.eu |date=2011-06-14 |accessdate=2013-09-05}}</ref> and taught physics at the same university.<ref>Monique Frize, ''Laura Bassi and Science in 18th Century Europe: The Extraordinary Life and Role of Italy's Pioneering Female Professor'', Springer, p. 174.</ref>
'''1742''' * United States: At only 16 years of age, Countess Benigna von Zinzendorf established the first all-girls boarding school in America, sponsored by her father Count Nicholas von Zinzendorf. Originally known as the Bethlehem Female Seminary upon its 1742 founding, it changed its name to Moravian Seminary and College for Women by 1913. 1863 proved the Germantown, Pennsylvania-based school’s most landmark year, however, when the state recognized it as a college and granted it permission to reward bachelor's degrees. As a result, most tend to accept Moravian as the oldest—though not continuously operational because of its current co-ed status—specifically female institute of higher learning in the United States.<ref name="thenewagenda1">{{cite web |url=http://www.thenewagenda.net/2011/07/28/11-momentous-female-firsts-in-academia/#more-31148 |title=Blog Archive » 11 Momentous Female Firsts in Academia |publisher=The New Agenda |date=2011-01-13 |accessdate=2012-08-20 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318113432/http://www.thenewagenda.net/2011/07/28/11-momentous-female-firsts-in-academia/#more-31148 |archivedate=2012-03-18 |df= }}</ref>
'''1751''' * Italy: [[Cristina Roccati]] became the third woman to receive a Ph.D. degree in Italy.<ref>William Clark, ''The Sciences in Enlightened Europe'', University of Chicago Press, 1999, p. 318.</ref> and taught physics at the Academia.
'''1783''' * United States: [[Washington College]] in [[Chestertown, Maryland|Chestertown]], Maryland, appointed the first women instructors at any American college or university, Elizabeth Callister Peale and Sarah Callister – members of the famous Peale family of artists – taught painting and drawing.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.washcoll.edu/about/buildings/kohl-gallery/history.php |title=Kohl Gallery: History |publisher=Washington College |accessdate=2013-03-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130403112714/http://www.washcoll.edu/about/buildings/kohl-gallery/history.php |archivedate=2013-04-03 |df= }}</ref>
'''1786''' * Russia: Catherine the Great opened free public primary and high school education to girls.<ref name="google2000">{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=VDBC0hupLqsC&pg=PA35 | author = Barbara Alpern Engel | title = Women in Russia, 1700–2000 | publisher = Cambridge University Press | year = 2004 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180401160745/https://books.google.com/books?id=VDBC0hupLqsC&pg=PA35 | archivedate = 2018-04-01 | df = }}</ref>
'''1787''' * Germany: Dorothea Schlözer became the first German woman to earn a PhD from Georg-August Universität Göttingen.
'''1788''' * Sweden: [[Aurora Liljenroth]] became the first female college graduate.
==19th century== ===1800-1849=== '''1803''' * United States: Bradford Academy in Bradford, Massachusetts was the first higher educational institution to admit women in Massachusetts. It was founded as a co-educational institution, but became exclusively for women in 1837.
'''1818''' * India: Western Christian missionaries opened the first schools in India open to girls.<ref name="Bharati Ray">Bharati Ray:Women of India: Colonial and Post-colonial Periods, 2005</ref>
'''1822''' * Serbia: Girls were allowed to attend elementary schools with boys up until the fourth grade.<ref name="Natalija Matić Zrnić 1956">Natalija Matić Zrnić, Jill A. Irvine & Carol S. Lilly: Natalija. Life in the Balkan Powder Keg 1880–1956. Central European University Press. 2008</ref>
'''1823''' * Argentina: the charitable Beneficial Society was charged by the government to establish and control (private) elementary schools for girls (they retain the control of the schools for girls until 1876).<ref name=Carlson>{{cite book | first = Marifran | last = Carlson | title = ¡Feminismo!: The Woman's Movement in Argentina from its Beginnings to Eva Perón| year = 2003}}</ref>
'''1826''' * United States: The first American public high schools for girls were opened in New York and Boston.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jFY3CxmHk4cC&pg=PA113&lpg=PA113&dq=girl+geometry+1829&source=bl&ots=gHk5ySOaVc&sig=5IjxVTtJVG4kfU6d699H0D9PXs8&hl=en&ei=AOqYTcfjEeyx0QH5vpWCDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=girl%20geometry%201829&f=false |title=Chronology of women's history |date= |accessdate=2011-04-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180401160745/https://books.google.com/books?id=jFY3CxmHk4cC&pg=PA113&lpg=PA113&dq=girl+geometry+1829&source=bl&ots=gHk5ySOaVc&sig=5IjxVTtJVG4kfU6d699H0D9PXs8&hl=en&ei=AOqYTcfjEeyx0QH5vpWCDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=girl%20geometry%201829&f=false |archivedate=2018-04-01 |df= }}</ref>
'''1827''' * Brazil: the first elementary schools for girls and the profession of school teacher were opened.<ref name="autogenerated1">A companion to gender history by: Teresa A. Meade, Merry E. Wiesner-Hanks</ref>
'''1829''' * United States: The first public examination of an American girl in [[geometry]] was held.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O4kEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA36&lpg=PA36&dq=the+first+public+examination+of+a+girl+in+geometry+(1829)&source=bl&ots=iP5ShzK5u-&sig=sBOKjFQxaCHgVm10oM2EE4g1BNg&hl=en&ei=U-iYTdm4D-GS0QHBpZj6Cw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&sqi=2&ved=0CBQQ6AEwAA# |title=History of Woman Suffrage: 1848–1861, Volume 1 |page=36 |editor1=Elizabeth Cady Stanton |editor2=Susan B. Anthony |editor3=Matilda Joslyn Gage |editor4=Ida Husted Harper |date=1889 |accessdate=2011-04-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180401160745/https://books.google.com/books?id=O4kEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA36&lpg=PA36&dq=the+first+public+examination+of+a+girl+in+geometry+(1829)&source=bl&ots=iP5ShzK5u-&sig=sBOKjFQxaCHgVm10oM2EE4g1BNg&hl=en&ei=U-iYTdm4D-GS0QHBpZj6Cw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&sqi=2&ved=0CBQQ6AEwAA |archivedate=2018-04-01 |df= }}</ref>
;1830s * Egypt: In Egypt Christian missionaries were allowed to open elementary schools for girls.<ref name=Rubin>{{cite book|editor-first=Barry|editor-last=Rubin|title=The Middle East: A Guide to Politics, Economics, Society and Culture|year=2012|isbn=978-0765680945}}</ref>
'''1831''' * United States: As a private institution in 1831, [[Mississippi College]] became the first coeducational college in the United States to grant a degree to a woman. In December 1831 it granted degrees to two women, Alice Robinson and Catherine Hall.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nNnVX4gQdD0C&pg=PA23 |page=23 |title=Looking Back Mississippi: Towns and Places |last=Cooper |first=Forrest Lamar |publisher=University Press of Mississippi |year=2011 |isbn=9781617031489 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160126122852/https://books.google.com/books?id=nNnVX4gQdD0C&pg=PA23 |archivedate=2016-01-26 |df= }}</ref>
'''1834''' * Greece: Greece got compulsory prime education for both boys and girls, in parallel with the foundation of the first private secondary educational schools for girls such as the [[Arsakeio]].<ref name="auto4">{{cite book|editors=Joyce Goodman, James C. Albisetti & Rebecca Roger|year=2010|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hYzGAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA142|title=Girls' Secondary Education in the Western World: From the 18th to the 20th Century|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=978-0-230-61946-3}}</ref>
'''1834''' * Iran: The first modern school for girls was opened in Iran, Urmia.<ref>{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=CdzFJIE7f5oC&pg=PA185 | title = Iran and the Surrounding World: Interactions in Culture and Cultural Politics | editor-first = Nikki R. | editor-last = Keddie | editor2-first = Rudi | editor2-last = Matthee | year = 2002 | publisher = University of Washington Press | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180401160745/https://books.google.com/books?id=CdzFJIE7f5oC&pg=PA185 | archivedate = 2018-04-01 | df = }}</ref>
'''1837''' * United States: Bradford Academy in Bradford, Massachusetts, due to declining enrollment, became a single-sexed institution for the education of women exclusively.
'''1839''' * United States: Established in 1836, Georgia Female College in Macon, GA opened its doors to students on January 7, 1839. Now known as Wesleyan College, it was the first college in the world chartered specifically to grant bachelor's degrees to women.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wesleyancollege.edu/about/index.cfm |title=About Wesleyan |publisher=Wesleyancollege.edu |date=2015-08-14 |accessdate=2016-05-27 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160527072417/http://www.wesleyancollege.edu/about/index.cfm |archivedate=2016-05-27 |df= }}</ref>
'''1841''' * Bulgaria: In Bulgaria the first secular [[girls school]] made education and the profession of teacher available for women.<ref name="OxfordEncyclopedia">{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=EFI7tr9XK6EC&pg=PA189 | title = The Oxford Encyclopedia of Women in World History, Volume 1 | editor-first = Bonnie G. | editor-last = Smith | publisher = Oxford University Press | year = 2008 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160504025415/https://books.google.com/books?id=EFI7tr9XK6EC | archivedate = 2016-05-04 | df = }}</ref>
'''1842''' * Sweden: Sweden requires compulsory [[Elementary school]] for both sexes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ub.gu.se/kvinn/portaler/kunskap/historik/ |title=Göteborgs universitetsbibliotek: Kampen om kunskapen av Christina Florin, professor i kvinnohistoria |publisher=Ub.gu.se |date= |accessdate=2013-10-07 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219135325/http://www.ub.gu.se/kvinn/portaler/kunskap/historik/ |archivedate=2014-02-19 |df= }}</ref>
'''1843'''
* Ghana: [[Catherine Mulgrave]] arrived on the [[Gold Coast (British colony)|Gold Coast]] from [[Jamaica]] and subsequently established three boarding schools for girls at [[Osu, Accra|Osu]] (1843), [[Abokobi]] (1855) and [[Odumase Krobo|Odumase]] (1859) between 1843 and 1891.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Encounters_in_Quest_of_Christian_Womanho.html?id=a5loknGzxTQC|title=Encounters in Quest of Christian Womanhood: The Basel Mission in Pre- and Early Colonial Ghana|last=Sill|first=Ulrike|date=2010|publisher=BRILL|isbn=9004188886|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170330122402/https://books.google.com/books/about/Encounters_in_Quest_of_Christian_Womanho.html?id=a5loknGzxTQC|archivedate=2017-03-30|df=}}</ref>
'''1844''' * Finland: The foundation of the [[Svenska fruntimmersskolan i Åbo]] and its sister school Svenska fruntimmersskolan i Helsingfors in Helsinki.
'''1847''' * Belgium: [[elementary school]] for both genders * Costa Rica: first high school for girls, and the profession of teacher was opened to women.<ref name="google3">{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=xl1rbaPN7mIC&pg=PA36 | author = Ilse Abshagen Leitinger | title = The Costa Rican Women's Movement: A Reader | publisher = University of Pittsburgh Press | year = 1997}}</ref> *Ghana: [[Rosina Widmann]] opens vocational school for girls in January 1847, with the first classes in needlework for 12 girls at her home in [[Akropong]] in the Gold Coast colony<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Survivors_on_the_Gold_Coast.html?id=DvHYAAAAMAAJ|title=Survivors on the Gold Coast: The Basel Missionaries in Colonial Ghana|last=Schweizer|first=Peter Alexander|date=2000|publisher=Smartline Pub.|isbn=9789988600013|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Encounters_in_Quest_of_Christian_Womanho.html?id=a5loknGzxTQC|title=Encounters in Quest of Christian Womanhood: The Basel Mission in Pre- and Early Colonial Ghana|last=Sill|first=Ulrike|date=2010|publisher=BRILL|isbn=9004188886|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nana Opare Kwakye|first=Abraham|date=April 2018|title=Returning African Christians in Mission to the Gold Coast|url=https://www.euppublishing.com/doi/pdfplus/10.3366/swc.2018.0203|journal=Studies in World Christianity|volume=24|issue=1|pages=25–45|doi=10.3366/swc.2018.0203|issn=1354-9901|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9aacznGPxgEC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Missionary+Practices+on+the+Gold+Coast,+1832-1895&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiL7Pf_q9HbAhVCG6wKHXoCCX0Q6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=Missionary%20Practices%20on%20the%20Gold%20Coast,%201832-1895&f=false|title=Missionary Practices on the Gold Coast, 1832-1895|publisher=Cambria Press|isbn=9781621968733|language=en}}</ref>
'''1849''' * United States: [[Elizabeth Blackwell]], born in England, became the first woman to earn a medical degree from an American college, [[Geneva Medical College]] in New York.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nlm.nih.gov/changingthefaceofmedicine/physicians/biography_35.html |title=Changing the Face of Medicine | Dr. Elizabeth Blackwell |publisher=Nlm.nih.gov |date= |accessdate=2011-04-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628011813/https://www.nlm.nih.gov/changingthefaceofmedicine/physicians/biography_35.html |archivedate=2011-06-28 |df= }}</ref> * United Kingdom: [[Bedford College (London)|Bedford College]] opens in London as the first higher education college for women in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ucl.ac.uk/bloomsbury-project/institutions/ladies_college.htm|title=Ladies’ College|work=UCL Bloomsbury Project|publisher=UCL|accessdate=4 December 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306084022/http://www.ucl.ac.uk/bloomsbury-project/institutions/ladies_college.htm|archivedate=6 March 2016|df=}}</ref> * India: Secondary education for girls was made available by the foundation of the Bethune School.
===1850–1874=== '''1850''' * United States: Lucy Sessions earned a literary degree from Oberlin College, becoming the first black woman in the United States to receive a college degree.<ref name="nwhm">{{cite web |url=http://www.nwhm.org/online-exhibits/africanamerican/25.html |title=Claiming Their Citizenship: African American Women From 1624–2009 |publisher=Nwhm.org |date= |accessdate=2012-08-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120227155748/http://www.nwhm.org/online-exhibits/africanamerican/25.html |archivedate=2012-02-27 |df= }}</ref> * France: Elementary education for both sexes, but girls were only allowed to be tutored by teachers from the church.<ref name="Richard J Evans 1979">Richard J Evans (1979). Kvinnorörelsens historia i Europa, USA, Australien och Nya Zeeland 1840–1920 (The Feminists: Women's Emancipation Movements in Europe, America and Australasia, 1840–1920) Helsingborg: LiberFörlag Stockholm. {{ISBN|91-38-04920-1}} (Swedish)</ref> * Haiti: First permanent school for girls.<ref name="haiticulture.ch">{{cite web |url=http://www.haiticulture.ch/Reperes_chronologiques.html |title=Femmes d'Haiti : Repères chronologiques |publisher=Haiticulture.ch |date= |accessdate=2013-10-07 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120423012214/http://www.haiticulture.ch/Reperes_chronologiques.html |archivedate=2012-04-23 |df= }}</ref>
'''1851'''
* Ghana: [[Regina Hesse]] moved into the household of her mentor, [[Catherine Mulgrave]] and her spouse, [[Johannes Zimmermann]] to understudy the methods of pedagogy.<ref name=":3" /> She later became the de facto principal of Mulgrave's girls' school at [[Osu, Accra|Christiansborg]].<ref name=":3" />
'''1852''' * Nicaragua: Josefa Vega are granted dispensation to attend lectures at university, after which women are given the right to apply for permission to attend lectures at university (though not to an actual full university education).<ref>Victoria González-Rivera: Before the Revolution: Women's Rights and Right-Wing Politics in Nicaragua, 1821–1979, 2012</ref>
'''1853''' * Egypt: The first Egyptian school for females was opened by the Copts minority.<ref name=Rubin/> * Serbia: The first secondary educational school for females was inaugurated (public schools for girls having opened in 1845-46).<ref name="auto4"/> * Sweden: The profession of teacher at public primary and elementary schools was opened to both sexes.<ref>Inger Hultgren (Swedish): Kvinnors organisation och samhällets beslutsprocess (1982)</ref>
'''1854''' * Chile: First public elementary school for girls.<ref name="OxfordEncyclopedia"/>
'''1855''' * United States: [[University of Iowa]] becomes the first coeducational [[Public university|public]] or state university in the United States.<ref name=Roch>{{Citation | first = A.J. | last = May | title = University of Rochester History | url = http://www.lib.rochester.edu/index.cfm?PAGE=2319 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20051214181209/http://www.lib.rochester.edu/index.cfm?PAGE=2319 | archivedate = 2005-12-14 | df = }}</ref>
'''1857''' * Netherlands: Elementary education compulsory for both girls and boys.<ref name="google6">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aQQpAAAAYAAJ|title=The Modern Woman's Rights Movement|author=Kaethe Schirmacher|year=1912|publisher=Macmillan|others=Carl Conrad Eckhardt (trans.)|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130624133303/http://books.google.com/books?id=AqQPAAAAYAAJ|archivedate=2013-06-24|df=}}</ref> * Spain: Elementary education compulsory for both girls and boys.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lBSEAgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Educated+Woman:+Minds,+Bodies,+and+Women%27s+Higher+Education+in+Britain,+Germany,+and+Spain,+1865-1914&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi-5taWyoTMAhWIbT4KHUxWAfIQ6AEIHTAA#v=onepage&q=1857&f=false|title=The Educated Woman: Minds, Bodies, and Women's Higher Education in Britain, Germany, and Spain, 1865–1914|author=Katharina Rowold|publisher=Routledge|year=2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180401160745/https://books.google.com/books?id=lBSEAgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Educated+Woman:+Minds,+Bodies,+and+Women%27s+Higher+Education+in+Britain,+Germany,+and+Spain,+1865-1914&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi-5taWyoTMAhWIbT4KHUxWAfIQ6AEIHTAA#v=onepage&q=1857&f=false|archivedate=2018-04-01|df=}}</ref>
'''1858''' * United States: Mary Fellows became the first woman west of the Mississippi River to receive a baccalaureate degree.<ref name="nwhm2">{{cite web |url=http://www.nwhm.org/online-exhibits/education/Timeline.htm |title=NWHM Exhibit: The History of Women and Education |publisher=Nwhm.org |date= |accessdate=2012-08-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130507094229/http://www.nwhm.org/online-exhibits/education/Timeline.htm |archivedate=2013-05-07 |df= }}</ref> * Ottoman Empire: The first state school for girls is opened; several other schools for girls are opened during the following decades.<ref name=autogenerated8>Women in the Ottoman Empire by Eric R Dursteler, Oxford Reference Online</ref> * Russia: [[Gymnasium (school)|gymnasiums]] for girls.<ref name="google2000"/>
'''1859''' * Denmark: The post of teacher at public schools are opened to women.<ref name="kvinfo.dk">{{cite web|url=http://www.kvinfo.dk/side/342/ |accessdate=November 28, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120404224755/http://www.kvinfo.dk/side/342/ |archivedate=April 4, 2012 |title=Kvinders adgang til uddannelse og erhverv 1857–1995}}</ref> *Ghana: [[Rose Ann Miller]] started an all-girls' boarding school at [[Aburi]] under the auspices of the [[Basel Mission]].<ref name=":3" /> * Sweden: The post of college teacher and lower official at public institutions are open to women.<ref>{{cite web |author=Sidansvarig: KvinnSam |url=http://www.ub.gu.se/kvinn/artal/ |title=Göteborgs universitetsbibliotek: Årtalslistor |publisher=Ub.gu.se |date= |accessdate=2013-10-07 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203100226/http://www.ub.gu.se/kvinn/artal/ |archivedate=2013-12-03 |df= }}</ref>
'''1860''' * Norway: Women are allowed to teach in the rural elementary school system (in the city schools in 1869).<ref name="Lønnå, Elisabeth 2015">Lønnå, Elisabeth. (2015, 31. mars). Kvinners Rettigheter I Norge Fra 1814 Til 1913. I Store norske leksikon.</ref>
'''1861''' * Sweden: The first public institution of higher academic learning for women, [[Högre lärarinneseminariet]], is opened.
'''1862''' * United States: [[Mary Jane Patterson]] became the first African-American woman to earn a BA in 1862. She earned her degree from Oberlin College.<ref name="thenewagenda1"/>
'''1863''' * Serbia: The inauguration of the Women's High School in Belgrade, first high school open to women in Serbia (and the entire Balkans).<ref name="auto4"/>
'''1864''' * United States: [[Rebecca Crumpler]] became the first African-American woman to graduate from a U.S. college with a medical degree and the first and only black woman to obtain the Doctress of Medicine degree from [[New England Female Medical College]] in Boston, MA.<ref name="nwhm"/> * Belgium: The first official secondary education school open to females in Belgium.<ref name=OxfordEncyclopedia4vol>Bonnie G. Smith: The Oxford Encyclopedia of Women in World History: 4 Volume Set. Oxford University Press, USA, 2008</ref> * Haiti: Elementary schools for girls are founded.<ref name="haiticulture.ch"/>
'''1865''' * Romania: The educational reform granted all Romanians access to education, which, at least formally, gave also females the right to attend school from elementary education to the university.<ref name=autogenerated9>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uZY3mGlJfdMC&pg=PA37&lpg=PA37&dq=Sofia+Chrisoscoleu&source=bl&ots=ZUL-GZgdEz&sig=cc4pChth6_mA2pa_x9HMVJozt2E&hl=sv&sa=X&ei=QWTuUtX5DYjiywPqjIKYCg&ved=0CEcQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=Sofia%20Chrisoscoleu&f=false|title=Engendering Socialism: A History of Women and Everyday Life in Socialist Romania|publisher=|accessdate=10 April 2016}}</ref>
'''1866''' * United States: [[Lucy Hobbs Taylor]] became the first American woman to earn a dental degree, which she earned from the [[Ohio College of Dental Surgery]].<ref name="catalyst1">{{cite web |url=http://www.catalyst.org/publication/211/firsts-for-us-women |title=Firsts for U.S. Women |publisher=Catalyst |date= |accessdate=2011-04-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719161519/http://www.catalyst.org/publication/211/firsts-for-us-women |archivedate=2011-07-19 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://home.comcast.net/~thorsdag/LucyHobbsTaylor.html |title=Lucy Hobbs Taylor, First Female Dentist |publisher=Home.comcast.net |date= |accessdate=2011-04-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110305221541/http://home.comcast.net/~thorsdag/LucyHobbsTaylor.html |archivedate=2011-03-05 |df= }}</ref>
'''1866''' * United States: [[Sarah Jane Woodson Early]] became the first African-American woman to serve as a professor. [[Xenia, Ohio]]’s [[Wilberforce University]] hired her to teach Latin and English in 1866.<ref name="thenewagenda1"/>
'''1867''' * Switzerland: Zürich University formally open to women, though they had already been allowed to attend lectures a few years prior.<ref name="google7">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RhNl22fb5xIC&pg=PA185|title=Ladies in the Laboratory II: West European Women in Science, 1800–1900|author1-first=Mary R. S.|author1-last=Creese|author2-first=Thomas M.|author2-last=Creese|publisher=Scarecrow Press|year=2004|isbn=0-8108-4979-8}}</ref>
'''1868''' * Croatia: The first high school open to females.<ref name="google8">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0UpvTRpKCGMC&pg=PA39&lpg=PA39&dq=women's+rights+austria+1811&source=bl&ots=IqY4Dfxrvl&sig=1iJgPwIXYry3BQPIiODtPP1Ed1w&hl=sv&sa=X&ei=zyH2TpOIOYnf4QSohsGNCA&sqi=2&ved=0CE0Q6AEwBA#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Forging the Bubikopf Nation: Journalism, Gender, and Modernity in Interwar Yugoslavia|first=Marina|last=Vujnovic|publisher=Peter Lang|isbn=978-1-4331-0628-6|year=2009}}</ref>
'''1869''' * United States: [[Fanny Jackson Coppin]] was named principal of the [[Institute for Colored Youth]] in Philadelphia, becoming the first black woman to head an institution for higher learning in the United States.<ref name="nwhm"/> * Austria-Hungary: The profession of public school teacher is open to women.<ref name="Richard J Evans 1979"/> * Costa Rica: Elementary education compulsory for both girls and boys.<ref name="google3"/> * Ottoman Empire: The law formally introduce compulsory elementary education for both boys and girls.<ref name=autogenerated8 /> * Russia: University Courses for women are opened, which opens the profession of teacher, law assistant and similar lower academic professions for women (in 1876, the courses are no longer allowed to give exams, and in 1883, all outside of the capital is closed).<ref name="Richard J Evans 1979"/> * United Kingdom: Watt Institution and School of Arts, a predecessor of [[Heriot-Watt University]], admits women. Mary Burton persuaded the Watt Institution and School of Arts to open its doors to women students in 1869 and went on to become the first woman on the School’s Board of Directors and a life Governor of Heriot-Watt College. One of the first women to serve on Edinburgh Parochial and School Boards, Mary was a lifelong campaigner for women’s suffrage and an advocate for educational opportunities for all.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hw.ac.uk/services/docs/WattWomen.pdf|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171222050612/https://www.hw.ac.uk/services/docs/WattWomen.pdf|archivedate=2017-12-22|df=}}</ref> * United Kingdom: The [[Edinburgh Seven]] were the first group of matriculated undergraduate female students at any British university. They began studying medicine at the University of Edinburgh in 1869 and although they were unsuccessful in their struggle to graduate and qualify as doctors, the campaign they fought gained national attention and won them many supporters including Charles Darwin. It put the rights of women to a University education on the national political agenda which eventually resulted in legislation to ensure that women could study at University in 1877. * United Kingdom: [[Girton College]] opens as the first residential college for women in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.girton.cam.ac.uk/girtons-past|title=Girton's Past|publisher=Girton College|accessdate=4 December 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151213164905/http://www.girton.cam.ac.uk/girtons-past|archivedate=2015-12-13|df=}}</ref>
'''1870:''' * United States: The first woman is admitted to Cornell. * Finland: Women allowed to study at the universities by dispensation (dispensation demand dropped in 1901).<ref name="Clark2008">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NtitRt1uUXMC&pg=PA188|title=Women and Achievement in Nineteenth-Century Europe|page=188|first=Linda L.|last=Clark|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2008|isbn=9780521650984}}</ref> * United States: [[Ada Kepley]] became the first American woman to earn a law degree, from [[Northwestern University School of Law]].<ref>[http://www.lawcrossing.com/article/3887/Northwestern-University-School-of-Law-Chicago-Illinois/ Northwestern University School of Law, Chicago, Illinois<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720234225/http://www.lawcrossing.com/article/3887/Northwestern-University-School-of-Law-Chicago-Illinois/ |date=2011-07-20 }}</ref> * United States: [[Ellen Swallow Richards]] became the first American woman to earn a degree in chemistry, which she earned from [[Vassar College]] in 1870.<ref name="google">{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Women and American Politics|author=Ford, L.E.|year=2009|publisher=Facts On File, Incorporated|isbn=9781438110325|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cVtFJ5tvINsC}}</ref> * [[Ottoman Empire]]: The Teachers College for Girls are opened in Constantinople to educate women to professional teachers for girls school; the profession of teacher becomes accessible for women and education accessible to girls.<ref name=autogenerated8 /> * Spain: The [[Asociación para la Enseñanza de la Mujer]] is founded: promoting education for women, it establishes secondary schools and training colleges all over Spain, which makes secondary and higher education open to females for the first time.<ref>{{cite book|author=Jennifer Jenkins Wood|title=Spanish Women Travelers at Home and Abroad, 1850–1920: From Tierra del Fuego to the land of the Midnight Sun|publisher=Bucknell University Press|year=2014}}</ref> * Sweden: Universities open to women (at the same terms as men 1873).<ref name="Lilla Focus Uppslagsbok 1979">Lilla Focus Uppslagsbok (Little Focus Encyclopedia) Focus Uppslagsböcker AB (1979) {{sv icon}}</ref> The first female student is [[Betty Pettersson]].
'''1871'''
* Netherlands: [[Aletta Jacobs]] became the first female to get accepted at the University of Groningen. * United States: [[Frances Elizabeth Willard]] became the first female college president in the United States, as president of [[Evanston College for Ladies]] in Illinois.<ref name="catalyst1"/><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nFt6csjzc48C&pg=PA468&lpg=PA468&dq=frances+elizabeth+willard+%22first+female+college+president%22&source=bl&ots=GwLPliiwJ7&sig=_yrmAHe8bmLxWEIOK6uV1h0Pbmo&hl=en&ei=bRo7TbPMHou_gQfploHbCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEMQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=frances%20elizabeth%20willard%20%22first%20female%20college%20president%22&f=false |title=Historical dictionary of women's ... |date= |accessdate=2011-04-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180401160745/https://books.google.com/books?id=nFt6csjzc48C&pg=PA468&lpg=PA468&dq=frances+elizabeth+willard+%22first+female+college+president%22&source=bl&ots=GwLPliiwJ7&sig=_yrmAHe8bmLxWEIOK6uV1h0Pbmo&hl=en&ei=bRo7TbPMHou_gQfploHbCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEMQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=frances%20elizabeth%20willard%20%22first%20female%20college%20president%22&f=false |archivedate=2018-04-01 |df= }}</ref> * India: First training school for woman teachers.<ref name="Bharati Ray"/> * Japan: Women are allowed to study in the USA (though not yet in Japan itself).<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_OOeA2H5aKIC&pg=PA100|title=The History of Modern Japanese Education: Constructing the National School System 1872–1890|last=Duke|first=Benjamin|publisher=Rutgers University Press|isbn=978-0-8135-4403-8|year=2009}}</ref> * New Zealand: Universities open to women.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aTp21_wDlXQC&&pg=PA9|title=Redbrick and Bluestockings: Women at Victoria, 1899–1993|author1-first=Beryl|author1-last=Hughes|author2-first=Sheila|author2-last=Ahern|publisher=Victoria University Press|isbn=0-86473-244-9|year=1993}}</ref> * [[Harriette Cooke]] became the first woman college professor in the United States appointed full professor with a salary equal to that of her male peers.<ref name="nwhm2"/>
'''1872:''' * Sweden: First female university student: [[Betty Pettersson]] * Japan: Compulsory elementary education for both girls and boys.<ref>Routledge international encyclopedia of women, by Cheris Kramarae</ref> * Ottoman Empire: The first government primary school open to both genders.<ref name=Talhami>{{cite book |first=Ghada |last=Talhami |title=Historical Dictionary of Women in the Middle East and North Africa |year=2012}}</ref> Women's Teacher's Training School opened in Istanbul.<ref name="North Africa 1999">{{cite book|title=Women in the Middle East and North Africa: Restoring Women to History|author1-first=Guity|author1-last=Nashat|author2-first=Judith E.|author2-last=Tucker|year=1999|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=0-253-33478-0|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ndqLZK3ba8gC&pg=PA83|page=83}}</ref> * Spain: [[María Elena Maseras]] is allowed to enlist as a university student with special dispensation: having been formally admitted to a class in 1875, she was finally allowed to graduate 1882, which created a [[Precedent]] allowing females to enroll at universities from this point on.<ref name="Consuelo Flecha 1910">Consuelo Flecha: Las primeras universitarias en España, 1872–1910. Narcea Ediciones, 1996</ref>
'''1873:''' * United States: [[Linda Richards]] became the first American woman to earn a degree in nursing.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R0eSPstPtMcC&pg=PA271&lpg=PA271&dq=%22first+american+woman+to+receive+a+degree+in+%22&source=bl&ots=vd6e0zDZ0g&sig=WyH-JpXdTgoG0PZVqBYgV1a_Fbc&hl=en&ei=-YYjTamPMcKblgfB_ICrDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CCcQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=%22first%20american%20woman%20to%20receive%20a%20degree%20in%20%22&f=false |title=More than Title nine |date= |accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref> * Egypt: The first public Egyptian primary school open to females: two years later, there are 32 primary schools for females in Egypt, three of whom also offered secondary education.<ref name=Rubin/>
===1874–1899=== '''1874:''' * United States: The Board of Regents of the University of California ruled that women should be admitted on an equal basis with men. With the completion of North and South Halls in 1873, the university relocated to its Berkeley location with 167 male and 222 female students. In 1874 the first woman to graduate from the University of California was Rosa L. Scrivner with a Ph.B in Agriculture. * Iran: The first school for girls is founded by American missionaries (only non-Muslims attend until 1891).<ref name=Milani>Farzaneh Milani: Veils and Words: The Emerging Voices of Iranian Women Writers. Syracuse University Press, 1992</ref> * Japan: The profession of public school teacher is opened to women.<ref name="google10">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8UD158VM3nMC&pg=PA469|title=A Companion to the Anthropology of Japan|first=Jennifer|last=Robertson|publisher=Wiley|year=2008|accessdate=10 April 2016}}</ref> * Netherlands: [[Aletta Jacobs]] becomes the first woman allowed to study [[medicine]]. * United Kingdom: [[London School of Medicine for Women]] founded, the first medical school in Britain to train women.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ucl.ac.uk/bloomsbury-project/institutions/london_school_medicine_women.htm|title=London School of Medicine for Women|work=UCL Bloomsbury Project|publisher=UCL|accessdate=4 December 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305001824/http://www.ucl.ac.uk/bloomsbury-project/institutions/london_school_medicine_women.htm|archivedate=5 March 2016|df=}}</ref> * Germany: Russian mathematician [[Sofia Kovalevskaya]] became the first woman in modern Europe to gain a doctorate in mathematics, which she earned from the [[University of Göttingen]] in Germany.<ref name="britannica.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/323006/Sofya-Vasilyevna-Kovalevskaya|title=Sofya Vasilyevna Kovalevskaya (Russian mathematician) -- Encyclopædia Britannica|publisher=britannica.com|accessdate=2014-01-25|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140328100230/http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/323006/Sofya-Vasilyevna-Kovalevskaya|archivedate=2014-03-28|df=}}</ref> * Canada: [[Grace Lockhart]] became the first woman in the British Empire to receive a Bachelor's degree, graduating from [[Mount Allison University]] in Canada.<ref>[http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=A1ARTA0004741 Grace Annie Lockhart - The Canadian Encyclopedia]</ref>
'''1875:''' * Switzerland: [[Stefania Wolicka|Stefania Wolicka-Arnd]], a Polish woman, became the first woman to earn a PhD from the University of Zurich in Switzerland.<ref>{{cite book|last=Schwartz|first=Agata|title=Shifting Voices: Feminist Thought and Women's Writing in Fin-de-siècle Austria and Hungary|year=2008|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press - MQUP|isbn=9780773532861|page=248}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j7ePIpI9qVgC&pg=PA555&lpg=PA555&dq=%22Stefania+Wolicka%22+1875&source=bl&ots=739B0s2jU1&sig=pqZxVLPrex9-LJbOrL-nUg1aum8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=KbQoUs6MLJfe4AP9yIDQAw&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22Stefania%20Wolicka%22%201875&f=false |title=Women's Movements: Networks and Debates in Post-communist Countries in the ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-05 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221144530/https://books.google.com/books?id=j7ePIpI9qVgC&pg=PA555&lpg=PA555&dq=%22Stefania+Wolicka%22+1875&source=bl&ots=739B0s2jU1&sig=pqZxVLPrex9-LJbOrL-nUg1aum8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=KbQoUs6MLJfe4AP9yIDQAw&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22Stefania%20Wolicka%22%201875&f=false |archivedate=2016-12-21 |df= }}</ref> * Denmark: Universities open to women.<ref name="Lilla Focus Uppslagsbok 1979"/> * India: First women admitted to college courses, although with special permission (at Madras Medical College).<ref name="Bharati Ray"/>
'''1876:''' * Argentina: Girls are included in the national school system by the transference of the control of the private girls schools from the charitable Beneficent Society to the provincial government.<ref name=Carlson/> * Great Britain: Medical examining bodies given the right to certify women.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Fjf4YynnC90C&pg=PT197|title=A Brief History of Great Britain|last=Burns|first=William E.|publisher=Facts On File|year=2010|isbn=978-0-8160-7728-1}}</ref> * India: Women allowed to attend university exams at the Calcutta University.<ref name="Bharati Ray"/> * Italy: Universities open to women.<ref name="google11">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uyNBAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA150|title=Higher Education of Women in Europe|first=Helene|last=Lange|isbn=978-3-86741-434-0|year=2010}}</ref> * Netherlands: Universities open to women.<ref name="google11"/> * United States: Anna Oliver was the first woman to receive a Bachelor of Divinity degree from an American seminary (Boston University School of Theology).<ref name="archives.umc.org">{{cite web|url=http://archives.umc.org/interior.asp?ptid=1&mid=2619 |title=Timeline of Women in American Methodism |publisher=Archives.umc.org |date=2006-11-06 |accessdate=2010-11-19}}</ref>
'''1877:''' * United States: [[Helen Magill White]] became the first American woman to earn a Ph.D., which she earned at Boston University in the subject of Greek.<ref name="catalyst1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/facts/5/238723/Helen-Magill-White-as-discussed-in-Boston-University-university-Boston-Massachusetts-United-States |title=Facts about Helen Magill White: Boston University, as discussed in Boston University (university, Boston, Massachusetts, United States): - Britannica Online Encyclopedia |publisher=Britannica.com |date=1944-10-28 |accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://rmc.library.cornell.edu/ead/htmldocs/RMM04107.html |title=Guide to the Helen Magill White Papers, 1865–1938 |publisher=Rmc.library.cornell.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-04-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514011746/http://rmc.library.cornell.edu/EAD/htmldocs/RMM04107.html |archivedate=2011-05-14 |df= }}</ref> * Chile: Universities open to women.<ref name=OxfordEncyclopedia/><ref name="Miller1991"/> * New Zealand: [[Kate Edger]] became the first women to graduate from a university in New Zealand.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://royalsociety.org.nz/150th-anniversary/150-women-in-150-words/1867-1917/kate-edger/|title=Royal Society of New Zealand|publisher=[[Royal Society Te Apārangi]]|accessdate=15 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170816063252/https://royalsociety.org.nz/150th-anniversary/150-women-in-150-words/1867-1917/kate-edger/|archivedate=16 August 2017|df=}}</ref>
'''1878:''' * Austria-Hungary: Women allowed to attend university lectures as guest auditors.<ref name="google12">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8VTnVGp1Nq4C&pg=PA190|title=Bildung and Gender in Nineteenth-century Bourgeois Germany: A Cultural Studies Analysis of Texts by Women Writers|first=Cauleen Suzanne|last=Gary|year=2008}}</ref> * Bulgaria: Elementary education for both genders.<ref name="google13">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EFI7tr9XK6EC&pg=PA189|title=The Oxford Encyclopedia of Women in World History|publisher=|accessdate=10 April 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160504025415/https://books.google.com/books?id=EFI7tr9XK6EC|archivedate=4 May 2016|df=}}</ref> * United Kingdom: [[Lady Margaret Hall]], the first college in the [[University of Oxford]] to admit women, is founded.<ref>''Alden's Oxford Guide''. Page]] became the first American woman to earn a degree in architecture, which she earned from the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jh7ecV24_uAC&pg=PA372&dq=mary+l+page+architect&hl=en&ei=5rneTPmEAsXflgeAlondAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=book-thumbnail&resnum=1&ved=0CDIQ6wEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Almanac of Architecture & Design 2006 |date= |accessdate=2011-04-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160618005401/https://books.google.com/books?id=Jh7ecV24_uAC#v=onepage&q&f=false |archivedate=2016-06-18 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EIhMAAAAYAAJ&q=%22first+american+woman+%22+mary+l+page&dq=%22first+american+woman+%22+mary+l+page&hl=en&ei=pIgjTdSiNoSClAfb5aDWDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAg |title=Journal of the American Institute of ... |date=2010-03-03 |accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref> * United Kingdom: [[The University of London]] receives a supplemental charter allowing it to award degrees to women, the first university in the United Kingdom to open its degrees .<ref name="london">{{cite web|url=http://www.london.ac.uk/history.html|title=University of London: History|publisher=University of London|accessdate=12 January 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140209004448/http://www.london.ac.uk/history.html|archivedate=9 February 2014|df=}}</ref>

'''1883:''' * Australia: Julia Margaret Guerin, known as Bella Guerin, became the first woman to graduate from a university in Australia, graduating from the University of Melbourne in 1883.<ref name="vic">{{cite web|url=http://suchwaslife.blogs.slv.vic.gov.au/2013/07/10/bella-guerin-first-female-university-graduate-in-australia/#.UtLJH0ko4dk|title=Bella Guerin: first female university graduate in Australia « Such was life – State Library of Victoria|publisher=suchwaslife.blogs.slv.vic.gov.au|accessdate=12 January 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140112204759/http://suchwaslife.blogs.slv.vic.gov.au/2013/07/10/bella-guerin-first-female-university-graduate-in-australia/#.UtLJH0ko4dk|archivedate=12 January 2014|df=}}</ref> * Sweden: [[Ellen Fries]], First female Ph.D. promoted. * United Kingdom: [[Sophie Bryant]] becomes the first woman in Britain to earn a DSc.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www-history.mcs.st-andrews.ac.uk/Biographies/Bryant.html|title=Sophie Willock Bryant|publisher=[[University of St Andrews]]|accessdate=4 December 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304133841/http://www-history.mcs.st-andrews.ac.uk/Biographies/Bryant.html|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}}</ref> '''1885:''' * Sierra Leone: [[Adelaide Casely-Hayford]] became the first African woman study music at the [[State University of Music and Performing Arts Stuttgart|Stuttgart Conservatory]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sierra-leone.org/Heroes/heroes6.html|title=Sierra Leone Web - '''1984:''' * United States: The U.S. Supreme Court's 1984 ruling ''[[Grove City College v. Bell]]''<ref name="oyez">[http://oyez.org/cases/1980-1989/1983/1983_82_792 "The Oyez Project, Grove City College v. Bell"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905170922/http://www.oyez.org/cases/1980-1989/1983/1983_82_792 |date=2015-09-05 }}, 465 U.S. 555 (1984)</ref> held that Title IX applied only to those programs receiving direct federal aid.<ref name="EB">[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/597287/Title-IX "Title IX."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150604031040/http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/597287/Title-IX |date=2015-06-04 }} ''Encyclopædia Britannica''. 2009. Encyclopædia Britannica Online. 19 Nov. 2009</ref> The case reached the Supreme Court when [[Grove City College]] disagreed with the Department of Education's assertion that it was required to comply with Title IX. Grove City College was not a federally funded institution; however, they did accept students who were receiving [[Basic Educational Opportunity Grant]]s through a Department of Education program.<ref name="oyez"/> The Department of Education's stance was that, because some of its students were receiving federal grants, the school was receiving federal assistance and Title IX applied to it. The Court decided that since Grove City College was only receiving federal funding through the grant program, only that program had to be in compliance. The ruling was a major victory for those opposed to Title IX, as it made many institutions' sports programs outside of the rule of Title IX and, thus, reduced the scope of Title IX.<ref name="Suggs">Suggs, Welsh. ''A Place on the Team.'' Princeton, NJ.: Princeton University Press, 2005.</ref>
'''1987:''' * United States: [[Johnnetta Cole]] became the first black president of [[Spelman College]].<ref name="nwhm"/>
'''1988:''' * United States: The Civil Rights Restoration Act was passed in 1988 which extended Title IX coverage to all programs of any educational institution that receives any federal assistance, both direct and indirect.<ref name="now">[http://www.now.org/issues/title_ix/history.html "Legislative History of Title IX"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100624070911/http://www.now.org/issues/title_ix/history.html |date=2010-06-24 }} National Organization for Women. June 27, 2007.</ref>
'''1994:''' * United States: In 1994, the Equity in Athletics Disclosure Act, sponsored by congresswoman [[Cardiss Collins]], required federally assisted higher education institutions to disclose information on roster sizes for men's and women's teams, as well as budgets for recruiting, scholarships, coaches' salaries, and other expenses, annually.<ref name="cases">[http://bailiwick.lib.uiowa.edu/ge/historyRE.html "Landmark Title IX Cases in History"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928040642/http://bailiwick.lib.uiowa.edu/ge/historyRE.html |date=2011-09-28 }} Gender Equity in Sport. February 23, 2006.</ref>
'''1996:''' * United States: ''[[United States v. Virginia]]'', {{ussc|518|515|1996}}, was a [[List of landmark court decisions in the United States|landmark case]] in which the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] struck down the [[Virginia Military Institute]] (VMI)'s long-standing [[Men's college|male-only admission policy]] in a 7-1 decision. (Justice [[Clarence Thomas]], whose son was enrolled at VMI at the time, [[recusal|recused]] himself.)
==21st century== '''2001:''' * United States: [[Ruth Simmons]] became the eighteenth president of Brown University, which made her the first black woman to lead an Ivy League institution.<ref name="nwhm"/>
'''2005–2006:''' * United States: For the first time, more doctoral degrees are conferred on women then men in the United States. This educational gap has continued to increase in the U.S., especially for master's degrees where over 50% more degrees are conferred on women than men.<ref name="NCES" />
'''2006:''' * United States: On November 24, 2006, the Title IX regulations were amended to provide greater flexibility in the operation of single-sex classes or extracurricular activities at the primary or secondary school level.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.ed.gov/legislation/FedRegister/finrule/2006-4/102506a.html |title=Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Sex in Education Programs or Activities Receiving Federal Financial Assistance |journal=Federal Register |volume=71 |number=206 |date=October 25, 2006 |accessdate=2012-06-24 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120620084108/http://www2.ed.gov/legislation/FedRegister/finrule/2006-4/102506a.html |archivedate=June 20, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
'''2011:''' * India: In April 2011, the Institute for Buddhist Dialectical Studies (IBD) in Dharamsala, India, conferred the degree of [[geshe]] (a Tibetan Buddhist academic degree for monks and nuns) to [[Venerable Kelsang Wangmo]], a German nun, thus making her the world's first female [[geshe]].<ref name="huffingtonpost.com">{{cite news | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/michaela-haas/buddhism-women_b_862798.html | work=Huffington Post | first=Michaela | last=Haas | title=2,500 Years After The Buddha, Tibetan Buddhists Acknowledge Women | date=2011-05-18 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160113000236/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/michaela-haas/buddhism-women_b_862798.html | archivedate=2016-01-13 | df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mandalamagazine.org/2012/geshe-kelsang-wangmo-an-interview-with-the-worlds-first-female-geshe/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130415120506/http://www.mandalamagazine.org/2012/geshe-kelsang-wangmo-an-interview-with-the-worlds-first-female-geshe/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-04-15 |title=Geshe Kelsang Wangmo, An Interview with the World’s First Female Geshe « Mandala Publications |publisher=Mandalamagazine.org |date= |accessdate=2014-08-25 }}</ref>
'''2013:''' * Saudi Arabia: The Saudi government sanctioned sports for girls in private schools for the first time.<ref name="BryantSaudi">{{cite web |author=Christa Case Bryant |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/Olive-Press/2013/0505/Saudi-Arabia-sanctions-sports-for-girls-for-the-first-time |title=Saudi Arabia sanctions sports for girls for the first time |publisher=CSMonitor.com |date=5 May 2013 |accessdate=30 August 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130902130309/http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/Olive-Press/2013/0505/Saudi-Arabia-sanctions-sports-for-girls-for-the-first-time |archivedate=2 September 2013 |df= }}</ref> * Saudi Arabia: Mai Majed Al-Qurashi became the first woman to receive a PhD in Saudi Arabia, which was conferred by the [[King Abdullah University of Science and Technology]].<ref name="ibtimes">{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/saudi-arabia-woman-mai-majed-al-qurashi-becomes-countrys-first-woman-get-phd-1429392|title=Saudi Arabia Woman Mai Majed Al-Qurashi Becomes Country's First Woman to Get PhD|publisher=ibtimes.co.uk|accessdate=12 January 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140112214621/http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/saudi-arabia-woman-mai-majed-al-qurashi-becomes-countrys-first-woman-get-phd-1429392|archivedate=12 January 2014|df=}}</ref> * United Kingdom: It was announced that [[Ephraim Mirvis]] created the job of ma’ayan by which women would be advisers on Jewish law in the area of family purity and as adult educators in Orthodox synagogues.<ref name="thejc.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/153491/chief-rabbi-mirvis-launches-new-qualification-female-educators|title=Chief Rabbi Mirvis launches new qualification for female educators|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160322132516/http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/153491/chief-rabbi-mirvis-launches-new-qualification-female-educators|archivedate=2016-03-22|df=}}</ref> This requires a part-time training course for 18 months, which is the first such course in the United Kingdom.<ref name="thejc.com"/> * Tibet: Tibetan women were able to take the [[geshe]] exams for the first time.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/on-faith/wp/2013/06/07/buddhist-nun-professors-or-none// | work=The Washington Post | first=Michaela | last=Haas | title=Buddhist nun professors or none? – OnFaith | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130607162349/http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/on-faith/wp/2013/06/07/buddhist-nun-professors-or-none/ | archivedate=2013-06-07 | df= }}</ref>
'''2016:''' * Tibet: Twenty Tibetan Buddhist nuns became the first Tibetan women to receive [[geshe]]ma degrees.<ref>{{cite web|last=Nuns |first=Tibetan |url=https://tnp.org/geshema/ |title=Tibetan Buddhist Nuns Make History: Congratulations Geshema Nuns! - The Tibetan Nuns Project |publisher=Tnp.org |date=2016-07-14 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=July 15, 2016 |url=http://www.lionsroar.com/twenty-tibetan-buddhist-nuns-are-first-to-earn-geshema-degrees/ |title=Twenty Tibetan Buddhist nuns are first ever to earn Geshema degrees - Lion's Roar |publisher=Lionsroar.com |date=2016-07-15 |accessdate=2016-10-04 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161005144113/http://www.lionsroar.com/twenty-tibetan-buddhist-nuns-are-first-to-earn-geshema-degrees/ |archivedate=October 5, 2016 |df= }}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=November 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} '''Toi Whakaari: NZ Drama School''' is New Zealand's foremost national drama school. It is located in [[Wellington]], New Zealand, at a purpose built facility: Te Whaea: National Dance & Drama Centre. Toi Whakaari offers training in acting, costume construction, performing arts management - and design for stage and screen. Toi Whakaari caters to around 130 students annually, who study for up to three years.
The school produces up to six productions of various types a year, largely performed, crewed, designed by students.
Toi Whakaari is the sister school of the [[New Zealand School of Dance]].
==Name== ''Te Kura Toi Whakaari O Aotearoa: NZ Drama School'' is the official name of the school. The [[Māori language|Maori]] portion of the name translates to: a place of learning (Te Kura), [[performing arts]] (Toi Whakaari), in (O) New Zealand ([[Aotearoa]]). This titled was 'gifted' to the School in 1988 by Te Puni Kokiri (Ministry for Māori Development) in recognition of the School's bicultural work.
==History== Toi Whakaari was established in 1970 by the Queen Elizabeth II Arts Council, as the New Zealand Drama School,<ref>{{cite web |title=The rise of professional theatre, 1960 to 1980 |url=https://teara.govt.nz/en/actors-and-acting/page-3 |accessdate=4 September 2018}}</ref> with [[Nola Leigh Millar]] as its first director.
In 2005, its first year students were the subjects of a reality TV show, ''Tough Act''. 2010 saw Toi Whakaari celebrate its 40th Anniversary. This also coincided with a book launch of the school's turbulent 40-year history. The book, titled ''Transitions'', was written by Bill Guest, former Head of the [[Entertainment Technology]] Program & Associate Director.
Annie Ruth, one of the first acting graduates of the school, was director of the school from 1998-2011 when she was succeeded by the current director, Christian Penny.
==Qualifications offered==
The school offers the following tertiary qualifications: * Bachelor of Performing Arts (Acting) * Bachelor of Performing Arts (Management) * Bachelor of Design (Stage & Screen) * New Zealand Diploma in Scenic and Properties Construction * Diploma in Costume Construction (for Theatre, Film and Allied Industries)
New qualifications from 2019, pending NZQA approval * New Zealand Diploma in Costume Construction
On average, 200+ acting students audition for the school each year from around the country. Of these, about 50 are invited for a recall audition and further questioning before the panel selects the 20-24 first year entrants.

Máximo Gómez #72 |website = http://www.unapec.edu.do }} '''Universidad APEC''' (''Universidad Acción Pro-Educación y Cultura'') ('''UNAPEC''') is a private [[university]] located in [[Santo Domingo]], [[Dominican Republic]]. It was founded in 1965 under the name of '''Instituto de Estudios Superiores''' (Institute of Higher Studies). [[Management]], Spanish and Bilingual Executive Secretarial Science, and [[Accounting]], were the first majors offered by this university. In 1968, the government of the Dominican Republic granted APEC accreditation as a university with the right to award higher education degrees. The university changed its name to the current one (Universidad APEC) on August 11, 1983; such change having been approved by the Dominican government in 1985. == University's Board of Trustees== *Roberto Rodríguez Estrella-President *Antonio Alma Iglesias- Vice-president *Cristina Aguiar - Secretary *Pedro Pablo Cabral - Treasurer *Radhamés Mejía - ''Ex Officio'' Director == Schools and Colleges== *[[Accounting]] *[[Arts and Communication]] *[[Computer Science]] *[[Economic and Entrepreneurial Sciences]] *[[Engineering]] and [[Technology]] *[[Languages]] *[[Law]] *[[Management]] *[[Marketing]] *[[Tourism]] == External links == *[http://www.unapec.edu.do Universidad APEC website] *[http://dr1.com/students/guide Dominican Republic Student & University Guide]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{coord missing|Dominican Republic}} [[Category:Universities in the Dominican Republic]] [[Category:Education in Santo Domingo]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1965]]

{{Infobox university |name = University of Greenland |native_name = Kalaallit Nunaata Universitetia |established = 1987 |image = [[File:University of Greenland logo.png]]
[[File:Ilisimatusarfik-university-of-greenland.jpg|300px]] |type = |students = 650 |rector = Tine Pars |faculty = 14 |staff = 21 |city = [[Nuuk]] |country = [[Greenland]] |campus = |affiliations = [[UArctic]] |website = [http://www.ilisimatusarfik.gl www.ilisimatusarfik.gl] }} The '''University of Greenland''' ({{lang-kl|Ilisimatusarfik}}; {{lang-da|Grønlands Universitet}}) is [[Greenland]]'s only [[university]]. It is in the capital city of [[Nuuk]]. Most courses are taught in [[Danish language|Danish]], a few in [[Greenlandic language|Greenlandic]] and classes by exchange lecturers often in [[English language|English]]. The university had an enrollment of approximately 650 students in 2015, composed of mostly Greenlandic inhabitants. It has around fourteen academic staff and five technical-administrative employees.[http://www.ilisimatusarfik.gl/Home/OmIlisimatusarfik/tabid/60/Default.aspx About the University] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928222948/http://www.ilisimatusarfik.gl/Home/OmIlisimatusarfik/tabid/60/Default.aspx |date=2007-09-28 }}. "ca. 150 studenter; 14 lærere foruden rektor samt 5 teknisk-administrativt ansatte." The modest student population is due in part to the government's policy allowing students a free university education anywhere in Europe or North America, with most Greenlandic students going to university in Denmark.{{cite web |url=http://chronicle.com/subscribe/login?url=http%3A%2F%2Fchronicle.com%2Fche-data%2Farticles.dir%2Fart-42.dir%2Fissue-49.dir%2F49a04001.htm |title=Modest University Aims to Serve Greenland's Particular Needs |author=Kim A. McDonald |publisher=chronicle.com |accessdate=2007-12-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081202051748/http://chronicle.com/subscribe/login?url=http%3A%2F%2Fchronicle.com%2Fche-data%2Farticles.dir%2Fart-42.dir%2Fissue-49.dir%2F49a04001.htm |archivedate=2008-12-02 |df= }}{{cite book|author=Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Secretary-General|title=NORA Region: The Faroe Islands, Greenland, Iceland and Coastal Norway|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oeBAu1Ks0nQC&pg=PA67|accessdate=20 April 2012|date=1 January 2011|publisher=OECD Publishing|isbn=978-92-64-09762-9|page=67}} ==History== The University of Greenland was established in 1987 to provide local [[higher education]] for Greenland. It was originally located in the former [[Moravian Church|Moravian]] mission station of [[Neu Herrnhut]], and moved into a dedicated research complex, Ilimmarfik, in 2009. The university has a [[Danish krone|DKK]] 14.8 million budget. {{Cn|date=May 2016}} == Institutes == [[File:Ilimmarfik.jpg|thumb|right|''Ilimmarfik'' university Campus in [[Nuuk]]]] The university has four institutes:{{cite web |url=http://www.uarctic.org/formsOnOrgs.aspx?m=392&CompanyID=32 |title=Member survey report for: Ilisimatusarfik/University of Greenland |publisher=uarctic |accessdate=2007-12-03 }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * Institute of Learning * Institute of Nursing and Health Science * Institute of Social Science, Economics and Journalism * Institute of Culture, Language and History The university awards [[Baccalaureate degree]]s in all departments and [[Master's Degree]]s in all areas except Theology. Ph.D.-programmes have been offered and at the moment five students are taking the degree. ==Rector== [[Tine Pars]] became director of Ilisimatusarfik at the beginning of 2009 after the former rector, Ole Marquardt, resigned in protest on the new University Law in December 2007.https://sermitsiaqag.wordpress.com/2007/11/15/rektorer-kvitter-jobbet-i-protest/ ==Guest faculty== Due to the small number of faculty, many specialized classes are offered by guest faculty, often coming from Danish universities, but also coming from other countries. Guest faculty at Ilisimatusarfik are often specialists for research on Greenland, combining teaching at Ilisimatusarfik with their research while staying on Greenland. == Library == The university library holds approximately 30,000 volumes. == Notes and references == {{reflist}} == External links == *{{Official website|http://www.ilisimatusarfik.gl}} === Related === * [http://www.arktiskcenter.gl Arctic Technology Centre, a Department of DTU] {{coord|64|11|27|N|51|41|46|W|display=title}} {{Nuuk}} {{North America topic|List of universities in}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Greenland, University of}} [[Category:Education in Greenland]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1987]] [[Category:Nuuk|University of Greenland]] [[Category:Universities in Greenland]] [[Category:Greenlandic culture|University of Greenland]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Nuuk]] [[Category:Universities established in the 1980s]] [[Category:1987 establishments in Iceland]] {{university-stub}}
